description: A unique identifier for an analysis.
A description for an analysis, e.g. 'Correcting for age and season'.
A JSON object specifying the analysis.
A foreign key referencing the sccs_analysis table.
A unique identifier for a covariate analysis.
A name for a covariate analysis, e.g. 'Pre-exposure'.
Is the variable of interest (1 = yes, 0 = no).
A foreign key referencing the sccs_analysis table.

A unique identifier for a covariate.
A description for the covariate.

A unique identifier for an analysis.
The type of era (e.g. 'rx' for drugs).
A unique identifier, corresponding to the ID in the source table (e.g. cohort_definition_id in a cohort table, or the drug_concept_id in the drug_era table).
A name for the era. Is NULL for eras derived from cohorts.
Foreign key referencing the database.
A unique identifier for a set of exposures and an outcome.
A cohort ID.
A cohort ID.

If known, the true effect size. For negatitive controls this equals 1.
A foreign key referencing the sccs_analysis table.

Foreign key referencing the database.
Either 'age', 'season', or 'calendar time'.
Location of the knot. For age, the month since birth. For season, the month of the year. For calendar time, the month since 1-1-1970.
The estimated relative risk (i.e. the incidence rate ratio).
A foreign key referencing the sccs_analysis table.
A foreign key referencing the sccs_exposures_outcome_set table.
Foreign key referencing the database.
The parameter number in the censor model (starting at 1).
The fitted parameter value.
The type of censor model. Can be 'Weibull-Age'. 'Weibull-Interval', 'Gamma-Age', or 'Gamma-Interval'.
A foreign key referencing the sccs_analysis table.
A foreign key referencing the sccs_exposures_outcome_set table.
A foreign key referencing the sccs_covariate table. The identifier for the covariate of interest.
The estimated relative risk (i.e. the incidence rate ratio).
The lower bound of the 95% confidence interval of the relative risk.
The upper bound of the 95% confidence interval of the relative risk.
The two-sided p-value considering the null hypothesis of no effect.
The one-sided p-value considering the null hypothesis of IRR <= 1.
The number of subjects with at least one outcome.
The number of outcome events.
The number of observation periods containing at least one outcome.
The number of subjects having the covariate.
The total covariate time in days.
The number of continuous eras of the covariate.
The number of outcomes observed during the covariate time.
The number of days subjects were observed.
The log of the relative risk.
The standard error of the log of the relative risk.
The log of the likelihood ratio (of the MLE vs the null hypothesis of no effect).
The calibrated relative risk.
The lower bound of the calibrated 95% confidence interval of the relative risk.
The upper bound of the calibrated 95% confidence interval of the relative risk.
The calibrated two-sided p-value.
The calibrated one-sided p-value considering the null hypothesis of IRR <= 1.
The log of the calibrated relative risk.
The standard error of the log of the calibrated relative risk.
